subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: I do not use the Awl and Ah sounds, instead using On exclusively. The problem is not that I can t distinguish them; indeed, by listening carefully and
messageBody:
I do not use the Awl and Ah sounds, instead using
On exclusively.
The problem is not that I can't distinguish them;
indeed, by listening carefully and concentrating, I
can hear and speak each of these closely enough.
The problem is that my spoken vocabulary and those
of my current compatriots do not sufficiently
distinguish these sounds. I simply don't know which
words get which sound, and doubt I will ever catch up
with no exemplars readily available.

When I write QS I will use On exclusively because
that is safe; mis-assigning Awl and Ah would probably
be worse than simply eliding these distinctions.

The Japanese speaker's problems with R and L are
not simply producing them on demand; they can be
taught to produce both ends of what is a continuum in
their language.
The problem is teaching them to hear the difference
and apply it to learning vocabulary, so they can keep
track of which words get which sound.
The rolled or trilled R is much easier for anyone
to distinguish, and is much less ugly in my opinion
than the American or English R.


===========
Never insult anyone by accident.
- Robert A. Heinlein
